questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? ( INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: B
options.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: C
options.text: Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: D
options.text: Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gilbert syndrome is a common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme responsible for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year

options.label: B
options.text: Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age

options.label: D
options.text: Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An increase in length of 25 cm in the first year is a key indicator of adequate growth in infants.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the image. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Focal clonic seizure.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Focal clonic seizures in neonates involve repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups that are resistant to restraint and can be unifocal or multifocal.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with vitamin A deficiency? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bitot spots

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin A deficiency is specifically associated with Bitot spots, characterized by keratin deposits on the conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.
  • ➤ The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:
  • ➤ For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413
  • ➤ Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:
  • ➤ The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer
  • ➤ Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects presents to the OPD with hematuria. His renal biopsy on light microscopy was normal. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had Gr 5 CKD and is undergoing dialysis. Which of the following would be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alport syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, with characteristic findings on electron microscopy, including a "basket-weave" appearance of the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones would you generally expect a 3-year-old child to display? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spoon handling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By the age of 3 years, a child is typically expected to handle a spoon and feed themselves, while more complex motor and language skills develop later.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Measles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lethargy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: A child transfers an object from one hand to another. What does it signify? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ability to compare objects

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transferring an object from one hand to another in a child signifies their developing ability to compare objects, a cognitive milestone typically reached around 5.5 to 6 months of age.
  • ➤ Developmental Milestones in 1 st Yr of Life
  • ➤ Developmental Milestones in 1 st Yr of Life

questions.text: Fluid of choice for a child in shock with severe acute malnutrition is? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ringer lactate + 5% dextrose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) who are in shock, the fluid of choice is Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose to manage dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and prevent hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Viral myositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Viral myositis is characterized by muscle pain, especially in the calves, following a viral infection, with elevated CK levels and normal reflexes, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular conditions.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) West syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: A child with Celiac disease can be given: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac patients must avoid gluten-containing grains like barley, rye, oats, and wheat (BROW). Rice is a safe and gluten-free option for these patients.

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ataxia Telangiectasia is not true?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Selective absence of IgM

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ataxia Telangiectasia (AT) is a complex genetic disorder characterized by progressive neurological decline, immunodeficiency, and increased cancer risk. The incorrect statement among the options is the selective absence of IgM. In reality, the most common immunodeficiency in AT involves a reduction or absence of IgA, not IgM. Patients with AT typically exhibit normal IgM levels, but often have reduced levels of IgA, which is crucial in mucosal immunity, leading to their increased susceptibility to respiratory infections.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Premature ageing: Correct, AT is associated with premature ageing, which is part of the broader spectrum of symptoms due to its impact on cellular repair and increased oxidative stress.
  • • Option A. Premature ageing:
  • • Option C. Insulin-dependent Diabetes Mellitus: Correct, although less common than other features, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus can occur in AT due to pancreatic involvement.
  • • Option C. Insulin-dependent Diabetes Mellitus:
  • • Option D. Progressive Cerebellar Ataxia: Correct, this is one of the hallmark symptoms of AT, typically manifesting early in childhood and progressively worsening, often confining individuals to a wheelchair by adolescence.
  • • Option D. Progressive Cerebellar Ataxia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ataxia Telangiectasia is associated with a selective absence of IgA, not IgM, which contributes to the immunodeficiency seen in these patients, leading to recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022) High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) PT and APTT Bone marrow Peripheral blood smear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a child suspected of having thalassemia, High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and a peripheral blood smear are key investigations for diagnosis.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is presenting with short stature, the height of the child to parent’s height and the chronological age of the child corresponds to bone age, what is the likely condition the child is associated with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Familial short stature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In familial short stature, the bone age corresponds to the chronological age, and the child's short stature is consistent with their genetic potential.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: A neonate delivered at 38 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2.2 kg develops feeding intolerance and abdominal distension on the second day. Physical examination is unremarkable, and the sepsis screen is negative. PCV is observed to be 72%. Which of the following represents the best management option? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Partial exchange transfusion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A hematocrit of 72% in a 2-day-old neonate indicates neonatal polycythemia. Symptoms such as feeding intolerance and abdominal distension are common gastrointestinal manifestations of this condition. The appropriate management for symptomatic polycythemia with a hematocrit of 72% is partial exchange transfusion (PET). This procedure reduces the hematocrit to a safer level, decreasing blood viscosity and improving tissue perfusion.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hydration with IV fluids: While hydration can be useful for mild cases, it is insufficient for a neonate with symptomatic polycythemia and a high hematocrit.
  • • Option A. Hydration with IV fluids:
  • • Option C. Presumptive treatment for sepsis: This is not indicated as the sepsis screen is negative.
  • • Option C. Presumptive treatment for sepsis:
  • • Option D. Medical management for intestinal obstruction: This is not appropriate as the symptoms are due to polycythemia, not intestinal obstruction.
  • • Option D. Medical management for intestinal obstruction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best management for symptomatic neonatal polycythemia with a hematocrit of 72% is partial exchange transfusion.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urinalysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nephrotic syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies in urinalysis

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly and other CNS abnormalities, but macrocephaly is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atopic dermatitis typically presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions on flexural areas, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy.

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Any of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn may indicate occult spinal dysraphism, which includes conditions such as spina bifida occulta, spinal lipoma, and dermal sinus, all of which can be signs of underlying spinal abnormalities requiring thorough evaluation, typically starting with ultrasound and definitive imaging with MRI.

questions.text: Which one among the following has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rubella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rubella has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission among the options listed, though it can still cause serious fetal complications if transmitted during pregnancy.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: Where is the most common site for a venous ulcer to develop? (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: A
options.text: Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli

questions.correct_answer: A. Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Venous ulcers characteristically develop in the skin of the gaiter region, the area between the muscles of the calf and the ankle. The majority of ulcers develop on the medial side of the calf below the malleoli. This is the region where many of the Cockett perforators join the posterior tibial vein to the posterior arch vein (superficial vein). The chronic venous hypertension in this area leads to tissue damage and eventually ulceration when exposed to high venous and capillary pressures chronically.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli : While ulcers associated with short saphenous vein incompetence may develop on the lateral side of the leg, they are less common than medial ulcers. Option C. Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli : Venous ulcers rarely extend into the upper calf, and this location would be uncommon. Option D. Medial aspect of the thigh : Venous ulcers typically occur below the malleoli in the gaiter area rather than thigh.
  • • Option B. Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli : While ulcers associated with short saphenous vein incompetence may develop on the lateral side of the leg, they are less common than medial ulcers.
  • • Option B. Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli
  • • Option C. Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli : Venous ulcers rarely extend into the upper calf, and this location would be uncommon.
  • • Option C. Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli
  • • Option D. Medial aspect of the thigh : Venous ulcers typically occur below the malleoli in the gaiter area rather than thigh.
  • • Option D. Medial aspect of the thigh

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Venous ulcers most commonly occur on the medial aspect of the ankle below the malleoli (gaiter area) due to the presence of perforating veins and high venous pressure in this region, especially in patients with chronic venous insufficiency.

questions.text: Sign of effective neonatal resuscitation is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased heart rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate.

questions.text: The fetal adrenal gland production of which of the following is maximum? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DHEA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fetal adrenal gland produces the maximum amount of DHEA, which is a precursor for estrogen synthesis, critical for maintaining pregnancy and supporting fetal development.

questions.text: Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located in the proximal calf region. It is one of the important named perforator veins that forms a direct communication between the superficial and deep venous systems. Specifically, Boyd's perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the deep veins (posterior tibial vein) at the level of the proximal calf. This perforator is clinically significant in patients with chronic venous insufficiency as incompetence in this perforator can contribute to varicose veins and venous hypertension.
  • • proximal calf
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. In the proximal thigh : This location is typically associated with Hunterian perforators, not Boyd's. Option B. In the distal thigh : Dodd’s perforators are typically described in this location. Option D. In the distal calf : This location is associated with Cockett's perforators (ankle perforators), which connect the posterior arch vein with the posterior tibial vein.
  • • Option A. In the proximal thigh : This location is typically associated with Hunterian perforators, not Boyd's.
  • • Option
  • • A. In the proximal thigh
  • • Option B. In the distal thigh : Dodd’s perforators are typically described in this location.
  • • Option
  • • B. In the distal thigh
  • • Option D. In the distal calf : This location is associated with Cockett's perforators (ankle perforators), which connect the posterior arch vein with the posterior tibial vein.
  • • Option D. In the distal calf

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Boyd's perforator is located in the proximal calf, serving as an important communication between the great saphenous vein and deep posterior tibial vein. Its incompetence plays a significant role in the development of venous hypertension and varicose veins.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: The following finding can be seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parvovirus B19 infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the causative agent of the 5th disease (erythema infectiosum) as Parvovirus B19. Understand the clinical manifestations of the 5th disease, including the characteristic "slapped-cheek" rash, and differentiate it from other childhood viral infections such as HFMD and conditions like Kawasaki disease and molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) is characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in the morning, with preserved consciousness and a good response to sodium valproate.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cephal hematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum, confined by the bone edges, and does not cross suture lines.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child arrived with a history of fever, reddened and congested conjunctiva, along with skin exhibiting redness and peeling, as depicted in the provided images. A 2D echocardiogram revealed the presence of a coronary aneurysm. What constitutes the initial course of treatment for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IVIG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Kawasaki disease, the initial course of treatment involves the administration of IVIG to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms and other complications.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cri-du-chat syndrome is identified by a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, leading to distinctive clinical features such as a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

questions.text: A child presents with brown-colored urine and oliguria for the last 3 days. He has mild facial and pedal edema. His blood pressure is 126/90. He has 2+ proteinuria with >100 red cells/HPF and a few granular casts. His creatinine is 0.9, urea is 56. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PSGN

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency are indicative of PSGN.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEg/L

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperkalemia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with CF may present with hypokalemia and contraction alkalosis due to electrolyte losses.

questions.text: Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2 Weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond 2 weeks.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who is eagerly drinking water and skin pinch goes back slowly. Which category does the child belong according to IMNCI? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Yellow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the IMNCI color coding system:
  • ➤ Green indicates no dehydration. Yellow indicates some dehydration. Pink indicates severe dehydration.
  • ➤ Green indicates no dehydration.
  • ➤ Yellow indicates some dehydration.
  • ➤ Pink indicates severe dehydration.

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intussusception

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intussusception presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable mass, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by imaging showing the claw sign.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021) Hyponatremia Hypomagnesemia Hypocalcemia Hypernatremia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text: A child presented in the pediatric OPD with fever for past 5 days along with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis. The mother also complained of a non itchy rash that appeared just a day back starting from behind the ears involving the face and spreading to the trunk also involving palms and soles. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Measles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles is characterized by the "3 C's" (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis) and a non-itchy rash that spreads from behind the ears to the rest of the body, including the palms and soles.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: A newborn baby is born with a congenital defect. Identify the defect shown in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bladder Exstrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bladder Exstrophy is characterized by the bladder being exposed outside the body, appearing as a red mass in the lower abdomen with no covering membrane. It differs from other abdominal wall defects like omphalocele and gastroschisis, which involve the protrusion of abdominal contents with or without a protective sac.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID? ( INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Corticosteroids are recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children to manage inflammation and the severe immune response associated with the virus.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mouth-nose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Female pseudohermaphroditism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia, most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, typically presents as female pseudohermaphroditism, characterized by virilized genitalia in genotypic females (46, XX) at birth.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the dermatological condition shown in the image? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The dermatological condition shown in the image is characterized by a photosensitive rash. This type of rash typically occurs in areas exposed to sunlight, such as the face, neck, and hands. The condition depicted is pellagra, which is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin). Pellagra is associated with the "4 Ds": diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis, and death . The dermatitis in pellagra is often photosensitive, meaning it worsens with exposure to sunlight, which explains the rash seen in the image.
  • • "4 Ds": diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis, and death
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vitamin A: Deficiency in Vitamin A leads to conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia (dry eyes), not photosensitive rashes.
  • • Option A. Vitamin A:
  • • Option B. Vitamin B1: Deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine) causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, not the skin.
  • • Option B. Vitamin B1:
  • • Option C. Vitamin C: Deficiency in Vitamin C results in scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, and joint pain, but not typically photosensitive rashes.
  • • Option C. Vitamin C:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin) causes pellagra, which presents with a photosensitive rash among other symptoms like diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is characterized by a purpuric rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal complications such as hematuria and proteinuria, typically following the rash development.

questions.text: At what pressure is the pop-up valve released in bag and mask ventilation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 30-40 cm of H2O

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation releases at a pressure of 30-40 cm of H2O to prevent excessive pressure that could harm the patient.
